media:group.media:title: Vanazdor‚Äôs industrial past
media:group.media:description:
Nestled in the mountains of northern Armenia is Vanadzor - the country‚Äôs third largest city and the heart of the Lori region. The city was the central hub of Armenian industrial manufacturing during the Soviet Union.
To honor this heritage, Mit Mission held a 3 day event in Vanadzor. The program included various speakers and hands-on workshops.

entry.title: Soviet Displaced Persons and the Birth of the Cold War

media:group.media:title: Soviet Displaced Persons and the Birth of the Cold War
media:group.media:description:
Australian historian Sheila Fitzpatrick gave a talk entitled ‚ÄúLost Souls: Soviet Displaced Persons and the Birth of the Cold War‚Äù at a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The lecture took place on July 10 in Tbilisi.
Sheila Fitzpatrick is renowned for her expertise in Soviet and modern Russian history, particularly during Joseph Stalin‚Äôs rule.
This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.

entry.title: Tufenkian Foundation's 25 years of service and impact

media:group.media:title: Tufenkian Foundation's 25 years of service and impact
media:group.media:description:
Greg Bedian, Director of Operations at the Tufenkian Foundation, speaks with CivilNet about the Foundation's 25-year journey in Armenia and Artsakh, and its evolving role in the regions, particularly in light of the recent humanitarian challenges. Reflecting on past accomplishments and major setbacks, he shares insights on the Foundation‚Äôs commitment to developing regions such as Syunik, which are not only a safe haven for displaced families from Artsakh but also hubs for economic growth and opportunities.
